FSW.content: agreeing w/ Saussure that signifier/signified two sides of same paper, originary writing must still produce space & materiality of sheet itself
FSW.linkedContent: agreeing w/ Saussure that signifier/signified two sides of same paper, originary writing must still produce space & materiality of sheet itself

FSW.content: it is the materiality of signifier that is relinquished in translation > when materiality is reinstated, translation becomes poetry
FSW.linkedContent: it is the materiality of signifier that is relinquished in translation > when materiality is reinstated, translation becomes poetry

FSW.content: since materiality of signifier constitutes idiom of dream scene, dreams are untranslatable
FSW.linkedContent: since materiality of signifier constitutes idiom of dream scene, dreams are untranslatable

FSW.content: pure words and pure things: “theoretical fictions”; words can be treated as things because of spacing, materiality of mark
FSW.linkedContent: pure words and pure things: “theoretical fictions”; words can be treated as things because of spacing, materiality of mark

F.content: encrypted, coded text written on crypt is not written on a pre-existing partition, the partition is the material of the text
F.linkedContent: encrypted, coded text written on crypt is not written on a pre-existing partition, the partition is the material of the text

DS.content: deconstruction’s ceaseless dissymmetry (i.e. what Hyppolite calls Mallarmé’s “materialism of the idea”) works alongside possibility of deconstruction’s neutralizing moment, the “logic of the hymen” is neither negatively neutral, nor neutral at all
DS.linkedContent: deconstruction’s ceaseless dissymmetry (i.e. what Hyppolite calls Mallarmé’s “materialism of the idea”) works alongside possibility of deconstruction’s neutralizing moment, the “logic of the hymen” is neither negatively neutral, nor neutral at all

DS.content: supplementary “blank,” in marking itself, intervenes btwn all series, prevents semantic seriality from closing itself, c’est encore lui qui libère des effets de série > makes us take agglomerates for substances
DS.linkedContent: supplementary “blank,” in marking itself, intervenes btwn all series, prevents semantic seriality from closing itself, c’est encore lui qui libère des effets de série > makes us take agglomerates for substances

ATIA.content: Lacan’s materiality of speech/corporality of language

CHM.content: the hermeneut, the analyst, must first know language of patient, the immediate materiality of sign (move from sign to signified, obvious meaning to latent)
CHM.linkedContent: the hermeneut, the analyst, must first know language of patient, the immediate materiality of sign (move from sign to signified, obvious meaning to latent)

TR.content: mechanistic materiality w/out materialism or matter (p. 80)
TR.linkedContent: mechanistic materiality w/out materialism or matter (p. 80)

TR.content: no archive w/out body (Derrida prefers “body” to “matter”)
machineness (machinalité): materiality that’s not necessarily a corporeality, programming, repetition, iterability, technicity (cutting off from living subject)
TR.linkedContent: machineness (machinalité): materiality that’s not necessarily a corporeality, programming, repetition, iterability, technicity (cutting off from living subject)

TR.content: subjectile, very body of event, archival and auto-deictic body [re: Rousseau’s Confessions]
TR.linkedContent: subjectile, very body of event, archival and auto-deictic body [re: Rousseau’s Confessions]

TR.content: revelation of truth nothing w/out saving body of inscriptions
TR.linkedContent: revelation of truth nothing w/out saving body of inscriptions

TR.content: paradoxical antinomy of performative & event, the former neutralizes event in “I can” of mastery: vulnerability/finitude of body & corpus is limit of performative power
TR.linkedContent: paradoxical antinomy of performative & event, the former neutralizes event in “I can” of mastery: vulnerability/finitude of body & corpus is limit of performative power

TR.content: de Man’s materiality: not physical but prosaic resistance to any aesthetic form, not something, nothing, yet it works, materialism as formalism in this materiality w/out matter
TR.linkedContent: de Man’s materiality: not physical but prosaic resistance to any aesthetic form, not something, nothing, yet it works, materialism as formalism in this materiality w/out matter

TR.content: resistance of letter (force of resistance w/out material substance) affects body: dissociative, dismembering, disseminating [materiality w/out matter, formality w/out form]
TR.linkedContent: resistance of letter (force of resistance w/out material substance) affects body: dissociative, dismembering, disseminating [materiality w/out matter, formality w/out form]

TR.content: textual event inseparable from formal materiality of the letter
TR.linkedContent: textual event inseparable from formal materiality of the letter

TR.content: isolated from its rhetoric [its tropes], grammar is purely formal—de Man: radically formal, mechanical > no text can be produced w/out this formal, grammatical element
TR.linkedContent: isolated from its rhetoric [its tropes], grammar is purely formal—de Man: radically formal, mechanical > no text can be produced w/out this formal, grammatical element

TR.content: de Man’s materiality strategic/fictional not metaphysical
de Man associates his “materiality,” concept of textual event, w/ deconstruction & dissemination
TR.linkedContent: de Man associates his “materiality,” concept of textual event, w/ deconstruction & dissemination

TR.content: materiality: useful name for that which resists appropriation
TR.linkedContent: materiality: useful name for that which resists appropriation

TR.content: de Man: text as body (always retraceable to metaphor) displaced [deconstructed] by text as machine, in this process suffers loss of illusion of meaning [dis-figuration, de-metaphorization]
TR.linkedContent: de Man: text as body (always retraceable to metaphor) displaced [deconstructed] by text as machine, in this process suffers loss of illusion of meaning [dis-figuration, de-metaphorization]

TR.content: materiality would imply the effect of arbitrariness, machinelike value of arbitrary > the event supposes the arbitrary [tension btwn machine & event]
TR.linkedContent: materiality would imply the effect of arbitrariness, machinelike value of arbitrary > the event supposes the arbitrary [tension btwn machine & event]

D.content: Soller’s Numbers is exemplary re: the reader, cette fois enfin, the text shows (montrée) that a reader cannot choose his/her place in a text > does so by composing surfaces retournées & par une mise en scène matérielle exacte
D.linkedContent: Soller’s Numbers is exemplary re: the reader, cette fois enfin, the text shows (montrée) that a reader cannot choose his/her place in a text > does so by composing surfaces retournées & par une mise en scène matérielle exacte

TN.content: Levinas’ language is hostage to rhetoric as he describes what Derrida risks calling quasi-messianic: “not yet, from a future never future enough” where “caress aims at the tender”
TN.linkedContent: Levinas’ language is hostage to rhetoric as he describes what Derrida risks calling quasi-messianic: “not yet, from a future never future enough” where “caress aims at the tender”

FV.content: for Lacan, signifier’s materiality (not empirical) due to certain indivisibility and locality (found where it isn’t) > indivisibility & locality are indissociable—rivet us (nous river), make us arrive at that which properly links singular to signature: guarantee of unity of signifier
FV.linkedContent: for Lacan, signifier’s materiality (not empirical) due to certain indivisibility and locality (found where it isn’t) > indivisibility & locality are indissociable—rivet us (nous river), make us arrive at that which properly links singular to signature: guarantee of unity of signifier

FV.content: for signifier to be kept (pour que le signifiant se garde) in its letter—no partition (if divisible, always can be lost en route) > materiality—indivisibility—idealization—point de capiton (staples signifier to signified) [?]: Lacan determines letter (no matter what he says) at point of its meaning (ideality): letter escapes partition, movement [no wonder he calls this “materiality” “odd”]
FV.linkedContent: for signifier to be kept (pour que le signifiant se garde) in its letter—no partition (if divisible, always can be lost en route) > materiality—indivisibility—idealization—point de capiton (staples signifier to signified) [?]: Lacan determines letter (no matter what he says) at point of its meaning (ideality): letter escapes partition, movement [no wonder he calls this “materiality” “odd”]
